Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Biological Shape Spaces, Transforming Shape into Knowledge
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Biological Shape Spaces, Transforming Shape into Knowledge

This project will develop a framework to represent, analyze and interpret shapes extracted from images, supporting a wide range of biological investigations. The primary objectives are: (1) to develop a mathematical framework and computational tools for the quantification and analysis of shapes; (2) to integrate these computational models with machine learning and statistical inference methods to enable new discoveries, transforming imaging data into biological knowledge; (3) to deliver novel quantitative methodologies for shape analysis that start from a biological premise, rather than a purely geometric one. The aim is thus not only to quantitatively describe shape, but to develop methods for linking morphological variation to its underlying biological causes. To ensure that the project focuses on methods that are most promising to biology with significant breadth of application, model and tool development will be guided and supported by a set of diverse case studies, ranging from the sub-cellular to organismal scales.

Shape represents a complex and rich source of biological information that is fundamentally linked to underlying mechanisms and function. However, shape is still often examined on a qualitative basis in many disciplines in biology, an approach that is time consuming and prone to human subjectivity. While ad hoc quantitative methods do exist, they are often inaccessible to non-experts and do not easily generalize to a wide variety of problems. The inability of biologists to systematically link shape to genetics, development, environment, function and evolution often precludes advances in biological research spanning diverse spatial and temporal scales, from the movement of molecules within a cell to adaptive changes in organismal morphology. The primary goal of this project is to develop a new suite of widely applicable quantitative methods and tools into the study of biological shape to address the significant need for consistent and repeatable analysis of shape data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shape plays an important role in biological function, from how blood is pumped through a heart to how bats use their ears and noses to create complex sonar patterns. The purpose of this grant was to develop richer mathematical and algorithmic tools to analyze shape, and determine how well those tools work for specific biological applications. 

Heart development: In the early stages of heart development the heart is essentially a tube, which deforms (by twisting) over time to become the familiar four-chambered heart. How this happens is a complex interplay between the shape (which influences how the blood flows), sensing mechanisms in the cells (stresses and strains the cells feel while the tube contracts and expands), and cell growth. Simple mechanical defects, such as restricting the blood flow through the tube, can cause the heart to develop incorrectly. In this work we focused on analyzing the shape of an actual developing heart (captured in-vivo) and comparing it to one that has had blood flow restricted due to banding. To do this, we developed novel algorithms for transforming the raw data (3D images of the tissue) into a single deforming surface, and developed novel visualization techniques to tease out how the shape differs both over time and spatially for different hearts. This research has enabled us to describe mathematically how, for example, restricting the blood flow causes the entire heart tube to contract differently. This work has the potential to help understand how some congenital heart defects form.

Bat sonar: Bats are masters of navigating using sound - they make a "click" sound, which echoes off of objects in the environment and returns to their ears. By measuring how long it takes the click to return, they can determine how far away an object is. In order to figure out what direction the object is in, it turns out that bat ears and noses shape the sound wave so that different frequencies travel in different directions - for example, low frequencies might be directed at the ground while high frequencies are projected in front of them. Exactly how the geometry of the ears and noses do this shaping is not completely understood. In this research, we developed novel methods to analyze the shape of ears and noses for different species of bats - what's the same, and what's different between them? By using digital models of ears, we can do synthetic experiments that would be difficult to do with real bats, such as removing geometric structures and seeing how that affects the sonar pattern. Long term, the goal is to understand what geometric structures lead to what sonar features, so that sonar sensors can be developed for specific tasks.
